entry.title: Notes for Mathematical Methods for Physicists
entry.content:
<!doctype html>

Mathematical Methods for Physicist

NotesonMathematicalMethodsforPhysicists

Chapter1MathematicalPreliminaries

§1.1InfiniteSeries

◻ComparisonTest

Consider a convergent series {an} , we can use {an} to study the convergence of series {un} :

0≤un≤an⇒ {un} is convergent.

Similarly , consider a divergent series {an} , we can use {an} to study the convergence of series {un} :

un≥an≥0⇒ {un} is divergent.

◻CauchyRootTest

(an)1/n≤r<1⇒ {an} is convergent.

(an)1/n≥1⇒ {an} is divergent.

◻d′Alembert(orCauchy)RatioTest

an+1an ≤r<1⇒ {an} is convergent.

an+1an ≥1⇒ {an} is divergent.

limn→∞ (an+1an){<1,congvergent=1,divergent>1,indeterminate

At some crucial point , the test may fail. For example , an=1n (harmonic series) :

an+1an = nn+1<1

but we cannot find r (< 1) independent of n.

Since limn→∞an+1an =1 , the test fails.

◻Cauchy(orMaclaurin)IntegralTest

Consider f(x) a continuous , monotonic decreasing function , in which f(n)=an.

∫1∞f(x)dx≤∑n=1∞ an≤∫1∞f(x)dx+a1

We have an equation , it writes ,

∑n=N1+1N2f(n)=∫N1N2f(x)dx+∫N1N2(x−[x])f′(x)dx

proof :

RHS=∫N1N2f(x)dx+∫N1N2(x−[x])f′(x)dx=∫N1N2f(x)dx+∫N1N2xf′(x)dx−∫N1N2[x]f(x)dx=∫N1N2f(x)dx+∫N1N2xd(f(x))−∑n=N1N2−1n∫nn+1f′(x)dx=∫N1N2f(x)dx+N2f(N2)−N1f(N1)−∫N1N2f(x)dx−∑N1N2−1n(f(n+1)−f(n))=N2f(N2)−N1f(N1)−∑N1N2−1n(f(n+1)−f(n))=N2f(N2)−N1f(N1)+∑n=N1+1N2f(n)+N1f(N1)−N2f(N2)=∑n=N1+1N2f(n)

Then RHS=LHS.

Q.E.D◼

Alternative of the equation :

∑n=N1+1N2f(n)=∫N1N2f(x)dx+∫N1N2(x−[x]−12)dx+12 (f(N2)−f(N1))

In this kind of equation , the second part in the right hand side is a function that oscillates about zero.

◻MoreSensitiveTests

1.KummerTheorem

If limn→∞(anuNun+1−an+1)≥C>0 , where C is a constant , we have {un} is convergent if ∑nan−1 is convergent. And if ∑nan−1 is divergent , the more weak it diverges , the more powerful the theorem will be.

If limn→∞(anuNun+1−an+1)≤0 , we have {un} is divergent if ∑nan−1 is divergent.

proof :

uN+1≤(aNuN−aN+1uN+1)/CuN≤(aN−1uN−1−aNuN)/C...≤......⇒∑i=N+1nui=(aNuN−anun)/C<aNuN/C⇒Convergent
2.Gauss′sTest

For large n , unun+1=1+hn+B(n)n2 , we can know that

{h>1⇒convergenth≤1⇒divergent

◻AlternatingSeries

For series of the form ∑n=1∞(−1)n+1an , an>0 , we have Leibniz Criterion :

If an monotonically decreases , and limn→∞an=0 , then {an} converges.

proof :

R2n=(a2n+1−a2n+2)+(a2n+3−a2n+4)+···>0R2n=a2n+1−(a2n+2−a2n+3)−(a2n+4−a2n+5)−···<a2n+1⇒0<R2n<a2n+1

so when n↑,R2n↑.

Q.E.D◼

◻Absolute&ConditionalConvergence

Absolute convergence : the absolute value of its terms form a convergent series.

Conditional convergence : not the situation above.

◻OperationonSeries

∙ If an infinite series is absolutely convergent , the series sum is independent of the order in which the terms are added.

∙ An absolutely convergent series may be added termwise to , or subtracted termwise from , or multiplied termwise with another absolutely convergent series , and the resulting series will also be absolutely convergent.

∙ The series (as a whole) may be multiplied with another absolutely convergent series. The limit of the product will be the product of the individual series limits. The product series , a double series , will also convergent absolutely.

◻ImprovementofConvergence

The rate of convergence : to form a linear combination of our slowly converging series and one or more series whose sum is known.

For the known series , the following collection is particularly useful :

α1=∑n=1∞1n(n+1)=1α2=∑n=1∞1n(n+1)(n+2)=14α3=∑n=1∞1n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3)=118...αp=∑n=1∞1n(n+1)···(n+p)=1p·p!

The series we want to sum and one or more known series (multiplied by coefficient) are combined term by term. The coefficients in the linear combination are chosen to cancel the most slowly converging terms.

◻RearrangementofDoubleSeries

For S=∑m=0∞∑n=0∞an,m ,

rearrangementofS={∑p=0∞∑q=0pap−q,q∑q=0∞∑p=q∞ap−q,q∑r=0∞∑s=0[r/2]as,r−2s

§1.2SeriesofFunctions

Let's extend our concept of infinite series to include series of functions :

sn(x)=u1(x)+u2(x)+···+un(x)S(x)=∑n=1∞un(x)=limn→∞sn(x)

◻UniformConvergence

If for any small ϵ>1 , there exists a number N , independent of x in the interval [a,b] (that is , a<x<b) such that ,

|S(x)−sn(x)|<ϵ,foralln≥N

Then the series is said to be uniformly convergent.

◻WeierstrassM(Majorant)Test

If we can construct a series of numbers ∑i=1∞Mi , in which Mi≥|ui(x)| for all x in the interval [a,b] , and ∑i=1∞Mi is convergent , then our series ui(x) will be uniformly convergent in [a,b].

proof :

∑i=n+1∞Mi<ϵ,∑i=n+1∞Mi>∑i=n+1∞ui(x)⇒∑i=n+1∞ui(x)<ϵ⇒|S(x)−sn(x)|=|∑i=n+1∞ui(x)|<ϵ

Uniform convergence has nothing with absolute convergence. But M test can only establish for absolutely convergent series.

◻Abel′sTest

A somewhat more delicate test for uniform convergence has been given by Abel. If un(x) can be written in the uniform anfn(x) , and

  1. The an form a convergent series , ∑nan=A.
  2. For all x in [a,b] the functions fn(x) are monotonically decreasing in n , that is , fn+1(x)≤fn(x).
  3. For all x in [a,b] , all the fn(x) are bounded in the range 0≤fn(x)≤M , where M is independent of x.

Then ∑nun(x) converges uniformly in [a,b]. This method is especially useful in analyzing the convergence of power series.

◻PropertiesofUniformlyConvergentSeries

If a series ∑nun(x) is uniformly convergent in [a,b] and the individual terms un(x) are continuous ,

  1. The series sum S(x)=∑n=1∞un(x) is also continuous ,
  2. ∫abS(x)dx=∑n=1∞∫abun(x) ,
  3. if the following additional conditions are also satisfied , then ∑n=1∞dun(x)dx is uniformly convergent in [a,b] : dun(x)dx is continuous in [a,b].

The first and second conditions are always right in physics , but the third is not because it is more restrictive.

◻Taylor′sExpansion

We assume that our function f(x) has a continuous n-th derivative in the interval [a,b].

First , let's intergrate this n-th derivative n times :

∫axf(n)(x1)dx1=f(n−1)(x)−f(n−1)(a)∫ax(∫ax2f(n)(x1)dx1)dx2=f(n−2)(x)−f(n−2)(a)−(x−a)f(n−1)(a)∫ax(∫ax3(∫ax2f(n)(x1)dx1)dx2)dx3=f(n−3)(x)−f(n−3)(a)−(x−a)f(n−2)(a)−(x−a)22!f(n−1)(a)···

Finally ， after integrating for the n-th time ,

∫axdxn∫axndxn−1···∫ax2dx1·f(n)(x)=f(x)−f(a)−(x−a)f′(a)−(x−a)22!f″(a)−···−(x−a)n−1(n−1)!f(n−1)(a)⇒f(x)=f(a)+(x−a)f′(a)+(x−a)22!f″(a)+···+(x−a)n−1(n−1)!f(n−1)(a)+Rn

where the remainder , Rn , is given by the n-fold integral ,

Rn=∫axdxn∫axndxn−1···∫ax2dx1·f(n)(x)

We may convert Rn into a perhaps more pratical form by using the mean value theorem of integral calculus ,

∫axg(x)dx=(x−a)g(ξ)⇒Rn=∫axdxn∫axndxn−1···∫ax2dx1·f(n)(x)=(x−a)nn!f(n)(ξ)

Or applying Cauchy's mean value theorem of integral calculus ,

Rn=(x−ξ)n−1(x−a)(n−1)!f(n)(ξ)

When you adjust n properly , Rn→0. Then we have Taylor Expansion , which writes

f(x)=∑n=0∞(x−a)nn!f(n)(a)

◻PowerSeries

When a=0 , we have Maclaurin series ,

f(x)=f(0)+xf′(x)+x22!f″(0)+···=∑n=0∞xnn!f(n)(0)

◻PropertiesofPowerSeries

f(x)=∑n=0∞anxn , in which an is independent of x. If limn→∞|an+1an|=R−1 , then R is the radius of convergence , and the series converges for x∈(−R,R).

But the ratio / root test fails at endpoints , x=±R needs special attention. In M test , the series is uniformly and absolutely convergent in (−R,R).

◻UniquenessTheorem

The power-series representation is unique. Assume that

f(x)=∑n=0∞anxn,−Ra<x<Ra=∑n=0∞bnxn,−Rb<x<Rb

What we need to prove is that an=bn , for all n.

∑n=0∞anxn=∑n=0∞bnxn,−R<x<RinwhichR≤Ra,Rb

When x=0 , we have a0=b0. Then differentiate the series ,

∑n=0∞nanxn−1=∑n=0∞nbnxn−1,−R<x<RinwhichR≤Ra,Rb

When x=0 , we have a1=b1. ··· ···

Repeating the process , we will get an=bn.

Q.E.D◼

This theorem will be a crucial point in our study of differential equations , in which we develop power series solutions (For instance , in theoretical physics , there's perturbation theory in quantum mechanics).

◻IndeterminateForms

You can use the power-series representation of functions to prove L′Ho^pital′sRule :

limx→x0f(x)g(x)=limx→x0f′(x)g′(x)

(See exercise 1.2.12)

◻InversionofPowerSeries

Consider that y−y0=∑n=1∞an(x−x0)n , if we want to know x−x0=∑n=1∞bn(y−y0)n , we need to equate coefficients of (x−x0)n on both sides of the given equation.

b1=1a1b2=−a2a13b3=2a22a15−a3a14b4=5a2a3a16−a4a15−5a23a17···

§1.3BinomialTheorem

Binomial series is a extremely significant application of the Maclaurin series. Let f(x)=(1+x)m , in which m∈R. Then ,

(1+x)m=1+mx+m(m−1)2!x2+···+Rn

For this function , the remainder is

Rn=xnn!(1+ξ)m−nm(m−1)···(m−n+1)

with ξ∈(0,x).

When x>0 , for n>m , (1+ξ)m−n is a maximum for ξ>0. So for x>0 , |Rn|≤xnn!|m(m−1)···(m−n+1)| , with limn→∞Rn=0 , when 0≤x<1.

Because the radius of convergence of a power series is the same for positive and negative x , the binomial series converges for −1<x<1. The endpoints cannot be determined.

Binomial Expansion :

(1+x)m=1+mx+m(m−1)2!x2+m(m−1)(m−2)3!x3+···

If m is a nonnegative integer , Rn for n>m vanishes for all x , corresponding to the fact that under those conditions (1+x)m is a finite sum.

Binomial Coefficients :

⟮mn⟯=m(m−1)···(m−n+1)n!
(1+x)m=∑n=0∞⟮mn⟯xn

In which , when n=0 , ⟮m0⟯=1.

1. When m is a positive integer , ⟮mn⟯=m!n!(m−n)!. That is Cmn=⟮mn⟯.

2. For negative integer m , set m=−p , there is

⟮−pn⟯=(−1)np(p+1)···(p+n−1)n!=(−1)n(p+n−1)!n!(p−1)!

3. For nonintegral m , it is convenient to use the Pochhammer Symbol , defined for general a and nonnegative integer n , as

(a)0=1,(a)1=a,(a)2=a(a+1),···(a)n+1=a(a+1)···(a+n)⟮mn⟯=(m−n+1)nn!

For addition , 0!!=(−1)!!=1 , because (2n)!!=2nn! , and (2n−1)!!=(2n)!!2nn!.

◻GeneralizedBinomialExpansion

1. For positive integer n , to polynomials ,

(a1+a2+···+am)n=∑n!n1!n2!···nm!a1n1a2n2···amnm

In which ∑i=1mni=n.

  1. (ddx)n(u(x)v(x))=∑i=0n⟮ni⟯(diu(x)dxi)(dn−iv(x)dxn−i)

§1.4MathematicalInduction

If a relation is valid for an arbitrary value of some index n , then it is also valid if n is replaced by (n+1).

§1.5OperationsonSeriesExpansionsofFunctions

For example ,

11+x=1−x+x2−x3+···⟹integralln(1+x)=x−12x2+13x3−14x4+···

§1.6SomeImportantSeries

ex=∑n=0∞xnn!=1+x+12x2+···sin(x)=∑n=0∞(−1)nx2n+1(2n+1)!=x−16x3+···sinh(x)=∑n=0∞x2n+1(2n+1)!=x+16x3+···cos(x)=∑n=0∞(−1)nx2n(2n)!=1−12x2+···cosh(x)=∑n=0∞x2n(2n)!=1+12x2+···11−x=∑n=0∞xn=1+x+···ln(1+x)=∑n=0∞(−1)n−1xnn=x−12x2+···
(1+x)p=∑n=0∞⟮pn⟯xn=∑n=0∞(p−n+1)nn!xn=1+p1!x+p(p−1)2!x2+⋯

§1.7Vectors

Scalar is defined as quantity that has algebraic magnitude only.

Vector is defined as quantity that has magnitude and direction. Vectors defined over a region are called vector fields.

◻BasicProperties

Let's just skip this part ···

◻Dot(Scalar)Product

Algebraic formula : A→⋅B→=∑iAiBi=∑iBiAi=B→⋅A→

( That is , if C→=A→+B→ , then A→⋅B→=12(|C→|2−|A→|2−|B→|2) )

Geometric formula : A→⋅B→=|A→||B→|cosθ , in which θ=<A→,B→>.

The projection of A→ in direction of B→ : Ab→=(A→⋅B→|B→|)B→|B→|

Schwarz inequality : |A→⋅B→|≤|A→||B→|

◻Orthogonality

If A→、B→≠0 , then

A→⋅B→=0⟺A→、B→areorthogonal.

§1.8ComplexNumbers&Functions

◻BasicProperties

A complex number is an ordered pair of two real variables , z=(x,y) (the order is significant) , in which i=(0,1) is the imaginary unit.

Addition : z1+z2=(x1,y1)+(x2,y2)=(x1+x2,y1+y2)

Multiplication : z1⋅z2=(x1,y1)⋅(x2,y2)=(x1x2−y1y2,x1y2+x2y1)

⇒i2=(0,1)⋅(0,1)=(−1,0)=−1⇒(x1+iy1)⋅(x2+iy2)=(x1x2−y1y2)+i(x1y2+x2y1)

For historical reasons , i and its multiples are known as imaginary numbers.

The space of complex numbers , sometimes denoted Z , by mathematicians , has the following formal properties :

1. It is closed under addition and multiplication , meaning that if two complex numbers are added or multiplied , the result is also a complex number.

2.It has a unique zero number , which when added to any complex number leaves it unchanged and which , when multiplied with any complex number yields zero.

3.It has a unique unit number 1 , which when multiplied with any complex number leaves it unchanged.

4.Every complex number z has an inverse under addition (known as −z) , and every nonzero z has an inverse under multiplication , denoted z−1 or 1/z.

5.It is closed under exponentiation : if u and v are complex numbers , the uv is also a complex number.

Complex conjugation : z=x+iy⟺z∗=x−iy

⇒z⋅z∗=x2+y2⇒|z|=z⋅z∗

Division :

z′z=z′⋅z∗z⋅z∗=(x′+iy′)(x−iy)x2+y2=xx′+yy′x2+y2+ixy′−x′yx2+y2

◻FunctionsintheComplexDomain

Among other things , that if a function is represented by a power series , we should , within the region of convergence of the power series , be able to use such series with complex values of the expansion variable. This is called the permanence of the algebraic form.

ez=1+z+12!z2+⋯eiz=1+(iz)+12!(iz)2+⋯=(1−12!z2+⋯)+i(z−13!z3+⋯)=cos(z)+isin(z)

which is called Euler equation.

when z=x+iy , then f(z)=u(x,y)+iv(x,y) has real part Re(f(z))=u(x,y) and imaginary part Im(f(z))=v(x,y).

◻PolarRepresentation

Skip that ⋯

z=reiθ , r is called modulus , θ is called argument or phase. Since additon on an Argand diagram is analogous to 2−D vector addition , it can be seen that

||z|−|z′||≤|z±z′|≤|z|+|z′|

Remember , w(z) is a mapping from xy plane to uv plane.

◻ComplexNumbersofUnitMagnitude

They are on the unit circle.

◻Circular&HyperbolicFunctions

cos(θ)=eiθ+e−iθ2,sin(θ)=eiθ−e−iθ2cosh(θ)=eθ+e−θ2,sinh(θ)=eθ−e−θ2⟹cosh(iz)=cos(z),sinh(iz)=isin(z)cos(nθ)+isin(nθ)=(cos(θ)+isin(θ))n
eiz=isin(z)+1−sin2(z)⟹arcsin(z)=−iln(iz+1−z2)arctan(z)=12iln(1−iz1+iz)arcsinh(z)=ln(z+1+z2)arctanh(z)=12ln(1+z1−z)

◻Power&Root

The polar form is very convenient for expressing powers and roots of complex numbers. Consider when z=reiφ , then

zn=rneinφz1/n=r1/nei(φ+2mπ)/n(m∈Z)

Actually , 1/n root has n different values.

◻Logarithm

ln(z)=ln(reiθ)=ln(r)+i(θ+2nπ)(n∈Z)

⟹ ln(z) has infinite number of values.

§1.9Derivatives&Extrema

Definition of derivative :

df(x)dx|x=limϵ→0f(x+ϵ)−f(x)ϵ

Variation & differential : df=dfdxdx

When f(x,y,z) , we have df=∂f∂xdx+∂f∂ydy+∂f∂zdz , in which ∂f∂x is called partial derivatives.

Cross derivatives : ∂2f∂x∂y=∂2f∂y∂x

1.The chain rule :

dfds=∂f∂xdxds+∂f∂ydyds+∂f∂zdzds

2.Consider f=f(x,y) , then :

(∂f∂x)y(∂x∂y)f(∂y∂f)x=−1

In Lagrangian mechanics , we often encounter formulas such as

ddtL(x,x˙,t)=∂L∂xx˙+∂L∂x˙x¨+∂L∂t

In which we need to distinguish between ddt and ∂∂t.

◻StationaryPoints

If we want to know how a function f changes if we move in various directions in the space of the independent variables , we can use

dfds=∂f∂xdxds+∂f∂ydyds+∂f∂zdzds

In which the direction is given by dxids.

It is often to find the minimum of a function f of n variables xi , i=1,2,⋯,n , and a necessary but not sufficient condition on its position is that dfds=0 , for ds in any direction. And this equals to ∂f∂xi=0 , i=1,2,⋯,n.

All points that satisfies the formula above are termed stationary :

{d2fds2>0⟹minimumd2fds2<0⟹maximumelse⟹saddle

§1.10EvaluationofIntegrals

⋆⋆⋆ Proficiency in the evaluation of integrals involves a mixture of experience , skill in pattern recognition , and a few tricks. ⋆⋆⋆

◻IntegrationbyParts

Legendre Transformation :

d(uv)=udv+vdu⟹udv=d(uv)−vdu⟹∫abudv=uv|ab−∫abvdu

◻SpecialFunctions

◻OtherMethods

An extremely powerful method for the evaluation of difinite integrals is that of contour integration in the complex plane. But this method will be presented in Chapter11. and not be dicussed here.

1.Integrals can often be evaluated by methods that involve integration or differentiation with respect to parameters , thereby obtaining relations between known integrals and those whose values are being sought.

2.Many integrals can be evaluated by first converting them into infinite series , then manipulating the resulting series , and finally either evaluating the series or recognizing it as a special function.

3.Simply using complex numbers aids in the evaluation of some integrals.

4.Recursion is useful in obtaining formulas for a set of related integrals.

◻MultipleIntegrals

∬f(x,y)dxdyor∫x1x2dx∫y1(x)y2(x)dy⋅f(x,y)or∫Sf(x,y)dA

In addition to the techniques available for integration in a single variable , multiple integrals provide further opportunities for evaluation based on changes in the order of integration and in the coordinate system used in the integral.

A significant change in the form of the 2−D or 3−D integrals can sometimes be accomplished by changing between Cartesian and polar coordinate systems.

◻Remarks:ChangesofIntegrationVariables

In a 1−D integration , a change in the integration variable from , say , x to y(x) involves two adjustments :

1.dx⟶(dxdy)dy

2.x1,x2⟶y(x1),y(x2)

If y(x) and x(y) is not single-valued , the process becomes more complicated , and we will not discuss it here.

For multiple integrals , we use Jacobian. For dxdy⟶Jdudv , J=∂(x,y)∂(u,v).

The computation of Jacobian will be discussed in Section4.4. Here , remember to determinate the transformed region.

§1.11DiracDeltaFunction

Definition :

δ(x)=0,x≠0f(0)=∫abf(x)δ(x)dx,(a<0<b)∫−∞∞δ(x)dx=1

No such function exists , (in the usual sense). However , the crucial property can be developed rigorously as the limit of a sequence of functions. The common seen examples are as follows :

They are of different uses as above.

For most physical purposes , the forms describing delta functions are quite adequate. However, from a mathematical point of view , the limits limn→∞δn(x) do not exist. To avoid the difficulty , label δ(x) a distribution , and write :

∫−∞∞δ(x)f(x)dx=limn→∞∫−∞∞δn(x)f(x)dx

◻Propertiesofδ(x)

∙ δ(−x)=δ(x)

∙ δ(ax)=1|a|δ(x)

Proof :

∫−∞∞f(x)δ(ax)dx=1|a|∫−∞∞f(y|a|)δ(y)dy=f(0)|a|

∙ ∫−∞∞f(x)δ(x−x0)dx=f(x0)

∙ If the argument of δ(x) is a function g(x) with simple zeros at points ai on the real axis (and therefore g′(ai)≠0) , then

δ(g(x))=∑iδ(x−ai)|g′(ai)|

Proof :

∫−∞∞f(x)δ(x)dx=∑i∫ai−εai+εf(x)δ[(x−ai)g′(ai)]dx(ε→0)

∙ Derivative of delta function :

∫−∞∞f(x)δ′(x−x0)dx=−∫−∞∞f′(x)δ(x−x0)dx=−f′(x0)

This is the definition of δ′(x−x0).

∙ In three dimensions , the delta function δ(r→) is intepreted as δ(x)δ(y)δ(z) , irrespective of the coordinate system in use. Thus , in spherical polar coordinates ,

∭f(r2→)δ(r2→−r1→)r22dr2⋅sinθ2dθ2⋅dφ=f(r1→)

∙ δ(t−x)=12π∫−∞∞eiω(t−x)dω (See Chapter20. , Fourier Integrals)

∙ Expansions of δ(x) are addressed in Chapter5. (Example5.1.7).

◻KroneckerDelta

The discrete analog of the Dirac delta function ,

δij={1,i=j0,i≠j

Usage examples :

∑i,jfijδij=∑ifiiorcn=11+δn02πL

Chapter2Determinants&Matrices

§2.1Diterminants

We begin the study of matrices by solving linear equations that will lead us to determinants and matrices. The concept of determinant and the notation were introduced by the renowned German mathematician and philosopher GottfriedWilhelmvonLeibniz.

◻HomogeneousLinearEquations

Suppose three unknowns x1,x2,x3 (or n equations with n unknowns) :

{a1x1+a2x2+a3x3=0b1x1+b2x2+b3x3=0c1x1+c2x2+c3x3=0

The problem is to determine under what conditions there is any solution , apart from the trivial one x1=x2=x3=0. Using vectors , we have a→⋅x→=0,b→⋅y→=0,c→⋅z→=0. These three vector equations have the geometrical intepretation that x is orthogonal to a→,b→,c→.

If the volume spanned by a→,b→,c→ given by determinant (or triple scalar product)

D3=(a→×b→)⋅c→=det(a→,b→,c→)=|a1a2a3b1b2b3c1c2c3|

is not zero , then there is the only trivial solution x→=0.

Conversely , if the aforementional determinant of the coefficient vanishes , then one of the row vectors is a combination of the other two. c→⊆plane(a→×b→) , only ratios of xi are relevant.

x1x3=a2b3−a3b2a1b2−a2b1x2x3=−a1b3−a3b1a1b2−a2b1

This is Cramer's Rule for homogeneous linear equation.

◻InhomogeneousLinearEquation

Simple example :

{a1x1+a2x2=a3b1x1+b2x2=b3
⟹x1=|a3a2b3b2||a1a2b1b2|x2=|a3a1b3b1||a1a2b1b2|

This is Cramer's Rule for inhomogeneous linear equation.

◻Definitions

Before defining a determinant , we need to introduce some related concepts and definitions.

∙ When we write two-dimensional (2−D) arrays of items , we identify the item in the nth horizontal row and the mth vertical column by the index set n,m ; note that the row index is conventionally written first.

∙ Starting from a set of n objects in some reference order (e.g. , the number sequence 1,2,3,⋯,n) , we can make a permutation of them to some other order ; the total number of distinct permutations that are possible is n! (choose the first object n ways , then choose the second in n−1 ways , etc.).

∙ Every permutation of n objects can be reached from the reference order by a succession of pairwise interchanges (e.g. , 1234→4132 can be reached by the successive steps 1234→1432→4132). Although the number of pairwise interchanges needed for a given permutation depends on the path (compare the above example with 1234→1243→1423→4123→4132) , for a given permutation the number of interchanges will always either be even or odd. Thus a permutation can be identified as having either even or odd parity.

∙ It is convenient to introduce the Levi-Civita symbol , which for an n-object system is denoted by εij... , where ε has n subscripts , each of which identifies one of the objects.

εij...=+1,ij...anevenpermutation,=−1,ij...anoddpermutation,=0,ij...notapermutation.

We now define a determinant of order n to be an n×n square array of numbers (or functions) , with the array conventionally written within vertical bars (not parentheses , braces , or any other type of brackets) , as follows :

Dn=|a11a12⋯a1na21a22⋯a2na31a32⋯a3n⋯⋯⋯⋯an1an2⋯ann|.

The determinant Dn has a value Dn=∑ij...εij...a1ia2j⋯ .

◻PropertiesofDeterminants

Take determinants of order 3 for example.

|a11a12a13a21a22a23a31a32a33|=−|a12a11a13a22a21a23a32a31a33|=|a11a21a31a12a22a32a13a23a33|k|a11a12a13a21a22a23a31a32a33|=|ka11a12a13ka21a22a23ka31a32a33|=|ka11ka12ka13a21a22a23a31a32a33||a11+b1a12a13a21+b2a22a23a31+b3a32a33|=|a11a12a13a21a22a23a31a32a33|+|b1a12a13b2a22a23b3a32a33|

∙ Any determinant with two rows equal , or two columns equal , has the value zero. To prove this , interchange the two identical rows or columns ; the determinant both remains the same and changes sign , and therefore must have the value zero.

∙ An extension of the above is that if two rows (or columns) are proportional , the determinant is zero.

∙ The value of a determinant is unchanged if a multiple of one row is added (column by column) to another row or if a multiple of one column is added (row by row) to another column.

∙ If each element in a row or each element in a column is zero , the determinant has the value zero.

◻LaplacianDevelopmentbyMinor

The fact that a determinant of order n expands into n! terms means that it is important to identify efficient means for determinant evaluation. One approach is to expand in terms of minors. The minor corresponding to aij , denoted Mij , or Mij(a) if we need to identify M as coming from the aij , is the determinant (of order n−1) produced by stiking out row i and column j of the original determinant. And we get

Dn=∑j=1naij(−1)i+jMij

◻LinearEquationSystems

For equation

{a1x1+a2x2+a3x3=h1b1x1+b2x2+b3x3=h2c1x1+c2x2+c3x3=h3

We define

D=|a1a2a3b1b2b3c1c2c3|.

Then we have

x1D=|a1x1a2a3b1x1b2b3c1x1c2c3|=|a1x1+a2x2+a3x3a2a3b1x1+b2x2+b3x3b2b3c1x1+c2x2+c3x3c2c3|=|h1a2a3h2b2b3h3c2c3|⟹x1=1D|h1a2a3h2b2b3h3c2c3|,x2=1D|a1h1a3b1h2b3c1h3c3|,x3=1D|a1a2h1b1b2h2c1c2h3|

This is the Cramer's Rule.

If D is nonzero , the above construction of the xi is definitive and unique , so that there will be exactly one solution to the equation set.

◻Determinants&LinearDependence

If the coefficients of n linear forms in n variables form a nonzero determinant , the forms are linearly independent ; if the determinant of the coefficients is zero , the forms exhibit linear dependence.

◻LinearlyDependentEquations

Situation 1

All the equations are homogeneous (which means all the right hand side quantities hi are zero). Then , one or more of the equations in the set will be equivalent to linear combinations of others , and we will have less than n equations in our n variables. We can then assign one (or in some cases , more than one) variable an arbitrary value , obtaining the others as functions of the assigned variables. We thus have a manifold (i.e. , a parameterized set) of solutions to our equation system.

Situation 2

A second case is where we have (or combine equations so that we have) the same linear form in two equations , but with different values of the right-hand quantities hi. In that case the equations are mutually inconsistent , and the equation system has no solution.

Situation 3

A third , related case , is where we have a duplicated linear form , but with a common value of hi. This also leads to a solution manifold.

◻NumericalEvaluation

There are many methods to evaluate determinants , even using computers. We use the Gauss Elimination to calculate determinants , which is a versatile procedure that can be used for evaluating determinants, for solving linear equation systems, and (as we will see later) even for matrix inversion.

Gauss Elimination : make the determinant into a form that all the entries in the lower triangle of the determinant. Then the only effective part is the product of thediagonal elements.

§2.2Matrices

Matrices are 2−D arrays of numbers or functions that obey the laws that define matrix algebra.

◻BasicDefinitions

A matrix is a set of numbers or functions in a 2−D square or rectangular array. A matrix with m (horizontal) rows and n (vertical) columns is known as an m×n matrix. When we introduced determinants , when row and column indices or dimensions are mentioned together , it is customary to write the row indicaters first.

A matrix for which n=m is termed square; One consisting of a single column (an m×1 matrix) is often called a column vector , while a matrix with only one row (therefore 1×n) is a row vector.

◻Equality

If A and B are matrices , A=B only if aij=bij for all values of i and j. A necessary but not sufficient condition for equality is that both matrices have the same dimensions.

◻Addition,Subtraction

Addition and subtraction are defined only for matrices A and B of the same dimensions , in which case A±B=C , with cij=aij±bij for all values of i and j. Addition is commutative (A+B=B+A) and also associative ((A+B)+C=A+(B+C)). A matrix with all elements zero , called a null matrix or zero matrix , can either be written as O or as a simple zero. Thus for all A ,

A+0=0+A=A

◻Multiplication(byaScalar)

Here we have B=αA , with bij=αaij for all values of i and j. This operation is commutative , with αA=Aα.

Note that the definition of multiplication by a scalar causes each element of marix A to be multiplied by the scalar factor , so there is

det(αA)=αndet(A)

◻MatrixMultiplication(InnerProduct)

Matrix multiplication is not an element-by-element operation like addition or multiplication by a scalar. The inner product of matrices A and B is defined as

AB=C,withcij=∑kaikbkj

This definition causes the ij element of C to be formed from the entire ith row of A and the entire jth column of B. And as you can realize , AB≠BA.

It is useful to define the commutator of A and B ,

[A,B]=AB−BA

which , as stated above , will in many cases be nonzero.

But , matrix multiplication is associative , meaning that A(BC)=(AB)C.

◻UnitMatrix

By direct matrix multiplication , it is possible to show that a square matrix with elements of value unity on its principal diagonal (the elements (i,j) with i=j) , and zeros everywhere else , will leave unchanged any matrix with which it can be multiplied. For example , the 3×3 unit matrix has the form

⟮100010001⟯

 

Appendix1Words

preliminary n. (pl. preliminaries) 初步

crucial adj. 至关重要的，极好的

monotonic adj. 单调的

termwise adv./adj. 逐项地/的

induction n. 归纳法

duplicated adj. 重复的

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

Quick Start

Create a new post

More info: Writing

Run server

More info: Server

Generate static files

More info: Generating

Deploy to remote sites

More info: Deployment
